maml:description.maml:para: Gets the Azure locations and their resource types
The Get-AzureLocation cmdlet gets the Azure resource types in each Azure location. You can use this cmdlet to determine whether a location supports a type of Azure resource.

A resource is a user-managed entity, such as a website, virtual machine, database server, or database. Every resource has a location in an Azure data center, such as "East Asia" or "North Europe." You specify the location when you create the resource.

Some locations support only certain types of resources. The locations and supported resource types are likely to change over time. Before you create your resources, you can use this cmdlet to find a location that supports the resource type.

Azure resources are members of a resource group, which is a collection of resources that are deployed as a unit. Resource groups have a location, but the group and its members do not need to be in the same location.
Gets the locations for the specified resource types. Enter the type in provider/type format, such as "Microsoft.Web/sites".
Gets only the locations that support resource groups. By default, Get-AzureLocation gets locations for all resource types.
Gets only the locations that support resource groups. By default, Get-AzureLocation gets locations for all resource types.
Gets the locations for the specified resource types. Enter the type in provider/type format, such as "Microsoft.Web/sites".

dev:type.maml:name: None. You can pipe input to this cmdlet by property name, but not by value.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet returns objects that represent Azure resource types.
Gets Azure resource groups
The Get-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet gets the Azure resource groups in your subscription. You can use the Name parameter to select resource groups by name. The default is all resource groups.

An Azure resource is a user-managed Azure entity, such as a database server, database, website, virtual machine, or storage account. An Azure resource group is a collection of Azure resources that are deployed as a unit.
Specifies the name of the resource group. Wildcards are not permitted. This parameter is optional. The default is all resource groups in the subscription
Specifies the name of the resource group. Wildcards are not permitted. This parameter is optional. The default is all resource groups in the subscription

dev:type.maml:name: None. You can pipe input to this cmdlet by property name, but not by value.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns an array of resource group objects

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get all resource groups
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\>Get-AzureResourceGroup Name: Contoso Location: West US Resources: Name Type Location =============== ======================= ======== ConstosoWebSite Microsoft.Web/sites West US sqlsvr03 Microsoft.Sql/servers West US sqldb01 Microsoft.Sql/databases West US
Name: EngineerBlog Location: East US Resources: Name Type Location =============== ======================= ======== EngineerBlog Microsoft.Web/sites West US EngSvr01 Microsoft.Sql/servers West US EngDB02 Microsoft.Sql/databases West US

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all resource groups in the subscription.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get resource groups by name
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureResourceGroup -Name EngineerBlog Name: EngineerBlog Location: East US Resources: Name Type Location =============== ======================= ======== EngineerBlog Microsoft.Web/sites West US EngSvr01 Microsoft.Sql/servers West US EngDB02 Microsoft.Sql/databases West US

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets Azure resource groups in your subscription that have names that begin with "eng".

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Get resource groups by other properties

dev:remarks.maml:para: The command uses the Where-Object and ForEach-Object cmdlets to get the names of resource groups that include database servers.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the deployment for a resource group.

The Get-AzureResourceGroupDeployment cmdlet gets the Azure resource group deployments in your subscription. You can use the Name (DeploymentName), ResourceGroupName, and ProvisioningState parameters to filter the deployments. The default is all deployments for resource groups in the subscription.
Gets only the deployments for the specified resource group. Wildcards are not permitted.
Gets only the deployment with the specified name. Wildcards are not permitted.
Gets only the deployment with the specified provisioning state. Valid values are NotProvisioned, Provisioning, Provisioned, and Deprovisioning.
Gets only the deployment with the specified name. Wildcards are not permitted.
Gets only the deployment with the specified provisioning state. Valid values are NotProvisioned, Provisioning, Provisioned, and Deprovisioning.
Gets only the deployments for the specified resource group. Wildcards are not permitted.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You can pipe input to this cmdlet by property name, but not by value.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet returns an array of objects that represent resource group deployments.
Creates a new Azure resource.
The New-AzureResource cmdlet creates an Azure resource, such as a website, virtual machine, SQL Azure database server, or SQL Azure database, and adds it to a resource group.
A resource is a user-managed Azure entity. A resource group is a collection of resources that are deployed as a unit. Every resource belongs to exactly one resource group.
Typically, you use a template to create a resource group (New-AzureResourceGroup) and its resources. Then, if necessary, you can use this cmdlet to add additional resources to it.
New-AzureResourceGroup is introduced in the version [BUGBUG] 0.7.5 of the Azure module. All parameters are introduced in the same module version, except as noted.
Specifies the names of the logical parents of a resource. This parameter is optional. Enter the fully qualified name of the parent resource, such as " Microsoft.Sql/servers/ContosoSQLSvr"

Use this parameter when the resource is a type that has parents. For example, every SQL Azure database is associated with a SQL Azure database server. A resource group is not a parent of its resources.
Specifies properties values for the properties of a resource. Enter a hash table in @{propertyName = propertyValue} format. This parameter is optional.

Use this parameter to specifies values of properties that are specific to a resource type. For example, an Azure SQL database has Edition and MaxSizeGB properties. To find the properties that you can set for each type of resource, look at a few gallery templates, such as the ones that the Get-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate cmdlet return.
For more information about hash tables in Windows PowerShell, see about_hash_tables (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=324844).
Specifies the location of the resource. This parameter is required. Enter an Azure data center location, such as "West US" or "Southeast Asia".

You can place a resource in any location that accepts resources of that type. The resource does not have to be in the same location your Azure subscription or the same location as its resource group. Resource groups can contain resources from different locations. To determine which resource types are permitted in each location, use the Get-AzureLocation cmdlet.
Specifies a name for a resource. This parameter is required. The resource name must be unique in [BUGBUG ??]. To determine whether a name is valid in Azure, use the Test-AzureName cmdlet.
Specifies the resource group for this resource. This parameter is required. Enter the name of a new or existing resource group. If the resource group doesn't exist, this cmdlet creates it for you.
A resource group is a collection of resources that are deployed as a unit. Every resource belongs to exactly one resource group.
Enter the type of the resource that you are creating, such as "Website" ("Microsoft.Web/Sites") or "Database" ("Microsoft.Sql/Databases"). This parameter is required.
Specifies the location of the resource. This parameter is required. Enter an Azure data center location, such as "West US" or "Southeast Asia".

You can place a resource in any location that accepts resources of that type. The resource does not have to be in the same location your Azure subscription or the same location as its resource group. Resource groups can contain resources from different locations. To determine which resource types are permitted in each location, use the Get-AzureLocation cmdlet.
Specifies a name for a resource. This parameter is required. The resource name must be unique in [BUGBUG ??]. To determine whether a name is valid in Azure, use the Test-AzureName cmdlet.
Specifies the names of the logical parents of a resource. This parameter is optional. Enter the fully qualified name of the parent resource, such as " Microsoft.Sql/servers/ContosoSQLSvr"

Use this parameter when the resource is a type that has parents. For example, every SQL Azure database is associated with a SQL Azure database server. A resource group is not a parent of its resources.
Specifies properties values for the properties of a resource. Enter a hash table in @{propertyName = propertyValue} format. This parameter is optional.

Use this parameter to specifies values of properties that are specific to a resource type. For example, an Azure SQL database has Edition and MaxSizeGB properties. To find the properties that you can set for each type of resource, look at a few gallery templates, such as the ones that the Get-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate cmdlet return.
For more information about hash tables in Windows PowerShell, see about_hash_tables (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=324844).
Specifies the resource group for this resource. This parameter is required. Enter the name of a new or existing resource group. If the resource group doesn't exist, this cmdlet creates it for you.
A resource group is a collection of resources that are deployed as a unit. Every resource belongs to exactly one resource group.
Enter the type of the resource that you are creating, such as "Website" ("Microsoft.Web/Sites") or "Database" ("Microsoft.Sql/Databases"). This parameter is required.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe input to this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: The cmdlet returns a PSResource object that represents the new resource.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create a New Database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureResource –Name sqldb2 –ResourceType "Microsoft.Sql/databases" –ResourceGroup Contoso –Location "West US" –ParentResourceName “Microsoft.Sql/servers/sqlserver01” Name: sqldb2 Location: West US Type: Microsoft.Sql/database ResourceGroup: Contoso Edition: Enterprise MaxSizeGB: 100 CollationName: SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command uses the New-AzureResource cmdlet to create the SqlDB2 database in the Contoso resource group. If the Contoso resource group doesn't exist, New-AzureResource creates it.
The command uses the Location parameter to place the new database in the "West US" data center, although the resource group and its resources are located in several different locations.
Azure SQL databases always have a parent database server. The command uses the ParentResourceName parameter to specify the database server.
The cmdlet returns a PSResource object that represents the new database.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Create a web site with property values
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$WebsiteProperties = @{name = "ContosoSite"; serverFarm = CS01; computeMode = "Shared"; siteMode = "Limited";}PS C:\>New-AzureResource -Name ContosoWeb -ResouceGroupName CRG01 -ResourceType WebSite -Location "South Central US" -PropertyObject $WebsiteProperties Name: ContosoWeb Location: South Central US Type: Microsoft.Web/sites ResourceGroup: CRG01 SiteName: ContosoSite ServerFarm: CS01 ComputeMode: Shared SiteMode: Limited

dev:remarks.maml:para: These commands create the ContosoWeb Azure website in the CRG01 resource group.

The first command creates a hash table of web site properties and saves it in the $WebsiteProperties variable. To find the properties that you can set for an Azure web site, use a gallery template, such as the ones that the Get-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate cmdlet return.
The second command uses the New-AzureResource cmdlet to create the web site. The value of the PropertyObject parameter is the hash table in the $WebsiteProperties variable. The

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Add a website to a resource group
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $rg = New-AzureResourceGroup -Name ContosoPortal -Location "West US" -GalleryTemplate WordPress -Domain Domain01 -ParameterFile ".\PortalParameters.rgcfg" PS C:\>New-AzureResource –Name sqldb03 –ResourceType "Microsoft.Sql/databases" –ResourceGroup ContosoPortal –Location "West US" –ParentResourceName "Microsoft.Sql/servers/ContosoServer01" –PropertyObject @{ “Edition” = “Enterprise”; “MaxSizeGB” = 100} Name: sqldb03 Location: West US Type: Microsoft.Sql/database ResourceGroup: ContosoPortal Edition: Enterprise MaxSizeGB: 100 CollationName: SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows a typical use of this cmdlet. The first command uses the New-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet to create the ContosoPortal resource group. The command uses the WordPress gallery template (Get-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate) and a JSON file, ".\PortalParameters.rgcfg" to specify values for the template-specific parameters, like the names of the ContosoServer01 database server, storage accounts, and web sites that are needed to deploy the web portal.

The second command uses the New-AzureResource cmdlet to add an additional database to the ContosoPortal resource group. The command uses the PropertyObject parameter to specify a hash table of values for the Edition and MaxSizeGB properties of the new database. For the other databases in the resource group, these values were specified in the PortalParameters.rgcfg resource group configuration file.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates an Azure resource group and its resources
The New-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet creates an Azure resource group and its resources and returns an object that represents the resource group.

Use this cmdlet to create a new resource group. To add a template to an existing resource group, use the New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment cmdlet. To add a resource to an existing resource group, use the New-AzureResource cmdlet.

An Azure resource is a user-managed Azure entity, such as a database server, database, website, virtual machine, or storage account. An Azure resource group is a collection of Azure resources that are deployed as a unit.

You can create a resource group with just a name and location, and then use the New-AzureResource cmdlet to create resources and add them to the resource group. However, typically, you use a resource group template, which is a model of a resource group for a complex cloud-based service, such as a web portal. The template includes parameter (placeholders) for required resources and configurable property values, likes names and sizes. You can find many templates in the Azure template gallery (Get-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate) and you can create your own templates. Azure resource group templates are text files in JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) format.

To find a gallery template and save it, use the Get-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate and Save-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate cmdlets. To use a gallery template, specify the template name. To create a custom resource group template, type the objects in any text editor or edit a gallery template.

To specify a gallery template, use the GalleryTemplateName parameter. To specify a custom template, use the TemplateFile parameter. To insure the integrity of your template, you can also use the TemplateHash, TemplateHashAlgorithm, and TemplateVersion parameters.

Each template has different parameters for configurable properties. To specify values for the template parameters, use a JSON-formatted parameter file (ParameterFile parameter) or a hash table of parameter names and values (ParameterObject parameter). If you are using a gallery template, you can also use the dynamic parameters the New-AzureResourceGroup adds to the parameter set when you use a particular gallery template.
NOTE: This cmdlet requires a storage account in the subscription. To create a storage account, use the New-AzureStorageAccount cmdlet.

Specifies the name of the deployment project for the resource group. Because the deployment properties are defined in a template, this parameter is valid only when you specify a template. This parameter is optional. The default value is a timestamp that represents that date and time that the resource group is created, such as "20140314150926".

Specifies the name of a storage account in the subscription. New-AzureResourceGroup saves the template file and its values in the storage account. This parameter is optional, but a storage account is required. The default value is the current storage account in the subscription. If you do not specify a storage account and the subscription does not have a current storage account and, the command fails.

To create a storage account, use the New-AzureStorageAccount cmdlet. To make the a storage account the "current storage account" for the subscription, use the CurrentStorageAccountName parameter of the Set-AzureSubscription cmdlet.
Provides a hash value of the template file. This parameter is optional and valid only when you specify a custom or gallery template.

Use this parameter to protect the integrity of a custom or gallery template file. To compute the file hash, use the New-Object cmdlet and a class in the System.Security.Cryptography namespace, such as the SHA512 class (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.security.cryptography.sha512(v=vs.110).aspx). Or, use a cmdlet that computes a hash value, such as the Get-Hash cmdlet in the PowerShell Community Extensions PSCX module (http://pscx.codeplex.com/).

Specifies the algorithm used to compute the hash value of the template, such as MD5 or SHA256. This parameter is optional in the cmdlet, but it is required when the TemplateHash parameter is used, and it is ignored when it is not used.

Specifies a particular version of the gallery or custom template. Enter the API version number, such as "2014-04-01-preview". New-AzureResourceGroup verifies that the specified template has the matching version and fails if it does not.
Specifies the location of the resource group. This parameter is required. Enter an Azure data center location, such as "West US" or "Southeast Asia".

You can place a resource group in any location. The resource group does not have to be in the same location your Azure subscription or the same location as its resources. Resource groups can contain resources from different locations. To determine which resource types are permitted in each location, use the Get-AzureLocation cmdlet.
Specifies a name for the resource group. This parameter is required. The resource name must be unique in [BUGBUG ??]. To determine whether a name is valid in Azure, use the Test-AzureName cmdlet.
You can use -Name or its alias, -ResourceGroupName.
If a resource group with that name already exists, the command fails, but you can use the Force parameter to overwrite the existing resource group.

Specifies the location of the resource group. This parameter is required. Enter an Azure data center location, such as "West US" or "Southeast Asia".

You can place a resource group in any location. The resource group does not have to be in the same location your Azure subscription or the same location as its resources. Resource groups can contain resources from different locations. To determine which resource types are permitted in each location, use the Get-AzureLocation cmdlet.
Specifies a name for the resource group. This parameter is required. The resource name must be unique in [BUGBUG ??]. To determine whether a name is valid in Azure, use the Test-AzureName cmdlet.
You can use -Name or its alias, -ResourceGroupName.
If a resource group with that name already exists, the command fails, but you can use the Force parameter to overwrite the existing resource group.

Specifies the path and name of a JSON file with the names and values of the template parameters. This parameter is optional. If a template has parameters, you must specify parameter values, but you can use this parameter or the ParameterObject parameter. For a gallery template, you can also use the dynamic parameters of the cmdlet.
To create a blank parameter file, use the Initialize-AzureResourceGroupTemplateFile cmdlet. To get the parameters of a template, use the Get-AzureResourceGroupTemplateParameter cmdlet.
Specifies the path and name of a custom template file. Enter the path to a template on the local computer or a remote computer that the local computer can access.

To create a blank template file, use the Initialize-AzureResourceGroupTemplateFile cmdlet. You can also create a custom template by editing a gallery template. To get and save gallery templates, use the Get-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate and Save-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate cmdlets.

Specifies the name of the deployment project for the resource group. Because the deployment properties are defined in a template, this parameter is valid only when you specify a template. This parameter is optional. The default value is a timestamp that represents that date and time that the resource group is created, such as "20140314150926".

Specifies the name of a storage account in the subscription. New-AzureResourceGroup saves the template file and its values in the storage account. This parameter is optional, but a storage account is required. The default value is the current storage account in the subscription. If you do not specify a storage account and the subscription does not have a current storage account and, the command fails.

To create a storage account, use the New-AzureStorageAccount cmdlet. To make the a storage account the "current storage account" for the subscription, use the CurrentStorageAccountName parameter of the Set-AzureSubscription cmdlet.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You can pipe input to this cmdlet by property name, but not by value.

maml:description.maml:para: New-AzureResourceGroup returns an object that represents the resource group.

maml:alert.maml:para: This cmdlet requires a storage account in the subscription. To create a storage account, use the New-AzureStorageAccount cmdlet.
If a resource group with this name already exists in the location [BUGBUG], the command fails.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create an empty resource group
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureResourceGroup -Name RG1 -Location "West US" Name: Contoso Location: West US Resources:

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a resource group that has no resources. You can use the New-AzureResource cmdlet to create resources and add them to this resource group.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Create a resource group from a custom template
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureResourceGroup –Name ContosoHosting –Location "West US" –TemplateFile .\ContosoHosting.json -TemplateHash F7BC574F4BAF57F0D6AB1CCAF27EDDC0 -TemplateHashAlgorithm MD5 -TemplateVersion "2014-04-01-preview" -DeploymentName ContosoHosting -ParameterFile .\ContosoHostingParms.json Name: ContosoHosting Location: Southeast Asia Resources: Name Type Location =============== ======================= ======== ContosoHosting Microsoft.Web/serverFarms West US Contoso Microsoft.Web/Sites West US

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates the "ContosoHosting" resource group from a custom template. It uses the TemplateFile parameter to specify the path and file name of the template file, and the TemplateHash and TemplateHashAlgorithm parameters to submit the hash value of the template file. Because the command does not specify a storage account, New-AzureResourceGroup uses the current storage account in the subscription.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Create a resource group from a gallery template
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>[BUGBUG]Get-AzureGalleryTemplate | Save-AzureGalleryTemplatePS C:\>New-AzureResourceGroup –Name ContosoHosting –Location "Southeast Asia" –TemplateFile .\ContosoHosting.json -TemplateHash F7BC574F4BAF57F0D6AB1CCAF27EDDC0 -TemplateHashAlgorithm MD5 -TemplateVersion 1.0.0 -DeploymentName ContosoHosting -ParameterFile .\ContosoHostingParms.json Name: ContosoHosting Location: Southeast Asia Resources: Name Type Location =============== ======================= ======== ContosoHosting Microsoft.Web/serverFarms West US Contoso Microsoft.Web/Sites West US

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to create a resource group from a gallery template.

maml:description.maml:para: Add an Azure deployment to a resource group.

The New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment cmdlet creates a resource group, its resources, and a deployment for the resource group. This cmdlet is similar to the New-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet, but it create a deployment package for the resource group, as well as the resource group.

An Azure resource is a user-managed Azure entity, such as a database server, database, website, virtual machine, or storage account. An Azure resource group is a collection of Azure resources that are deployed as a unit. A deployment is a set of properties that define how the resource group is uploaded to Azure and made available to its users. A deployment typically consists of a package file and configuration settings.

You can create a resource group deployment with just a resource group name, and then use the New-AzureResource cmdlet to create resources and add them to the resource group. However, typically, you use a resource group template, which is a model of a resource group for a complex cloud-based service, such as a web portal. The template includes parameter (placeholders) for required resources and configurable property values, likes names and sizes. You can find many templates in the Azure template gallery (Get-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate) and you can create your own templates. Azure resource group templates are text files in JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) format.

To find a gallery template and save it, use the Get-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate and Save-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate cmdlets. To use a gallery template, specify the template name. To create a custom resource group template, type the objects in any text editor or edit a gallery template.

To specify a gallery template, use the GalleryTemplateName parameter. To specify a custom template, use the TemplateFile parameter. To insure the integrity of your template, you can also use the TemplateHash, TemplateHashAlgorithm, and TemplateVersion parameters.

Each template has different parameters for configurable properties. To specify values for the template parameters, use a JSON-formatted parameter file (ParameterFile parameter) or a hash table of parameter names and values (ParameterObject parameter). If you are using a gallery template, you can also use the dynamic parameters the New-AzureResourceGroup adds to the parameter set when you use a particular gallery template.
NOTE: This cmdlet requires a storage account in the subscription. To create a storage account, use the New-AzureStorageAccount cmdlet.

Specifies the name of the deployment project for the resource group. The deployment name must be unique in [BUGBUG ??]. To determine whether a name is valid in Azure, use the Test-AzureName cmdlet. Because the deployment properties are defined in a template, this parameter is valid only when you specify a template. This parameter is optional. The default value is a timestamp that represents that date and time that the resource group is created, such as "20140314150926".
You can use -Name or its alias, -DeploymentName.

Specifies the name of a storage account in the subscription. New-AzureResourceGroup saves the template file and its values in the storage account. This parameter is optional, but a storage account is required. The default value is the current storage account in the subscription. If you do not specify a storage account and the subscription does not have a current storage account and, the command fails.

To create a storage account, use the New-AzureStorageAccount cmdlet. To make the a storage account the "current storage account" for the subscription, use the CurrentStorageAccountName parameter of the Set-AzureSubscription cmdlet.

Or, use a cmdlet that computes a hash value, such as the Get-Hash cmdlet in the PowerShell Community Extensions PSCX module (http://pscx.codeplex.com/).

Specifies the algorithm used to compute the hash value of the template, such as MD5 or SHA256. This parameter is optional in the cmdlet, but it is required when the TemplateHash parameter is used, and it is ignored when it is not used.

Specifies a particular version of the gallery or custom template. Enter the API version number, such as "2014-04-01-preview". New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment verifies that the specified template has the matching version and fails if it does not.

For a gallery template, you can also use the dynamic parameters of the cmdlet.
To create a blank parameter file, use the Initialize-AzureResourceGroupTemplateFile cmdlet. To get the parameters of a template, use the Get-AzureResourceGroupTemplateParameter cmdlet.

The default value is a timestamp that represents that date and time that the resource group is created, such as "20140314150926".
You can use -Name or its alias, -DeploymentName.

Specifies the name of a storage account in the subscription. New-AzureResourceGroup saves the template file and its values in the storage account. dev:type.maml:name: None. You can pipe input to this cmdlet by property name, but not by value.

maml:description.maml:para: New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment returns an object that represents the resource group deployment.

maml:alert.maml:para: This cmdlet requires a storage account in the subscription. To create a storage account, use the New-AzureStorageAccount cmdlet.
If a resource group with this name already exists in the location [BUGBUG], the command fails.

maml:description.maml:para: Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Deletes a resource group.

The Remove-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet deletes one or more resource groups in your subscription. It does not delete the resources in the resource group. To use this cmdlet, you must have [BUGBUG] permissions.
[BUGBUG]By default, Remove-AzureResourceGroup prompts you for confirmation. To suppress the prompt, use the Force parameter.
[BUGBUG]To avoid deleting resource groups by mistake, use the Confirm and WhatIf parameters.
Specifies the names of resource groups to delete. This parameter is required. Wildcards are not permitted.
Use -Name or its alias, -ResourceGroupName.
Suppresses the confirmation prompt.
Returns $true if the remove operation was successful and $false if it was not. By default, this cmdlet does not return any input.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Suppresses the confirmation prompt.
Specifies the names of resource groups to delete. This parameter is required. Wildcards are not permitted.
Use -Name or its alias, -ResourceGroupName.
Returns $true if the remove operation was successful and $false if it was not. By default, this cmdlet does not return any input.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You can pipe input to this cmdlet by property name, but not by value.

maml:description.maml:para: When you use the PassThru parameter, Remove-AzureResourceGroup returns $true if the operation succeeded and $false if it failed. Otherwise, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Remove a resource group
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureResourceGroup -Name -ContosoRG01 ConfirmAre you sure you want to remove resource group 'ContosoRG01'[Y] Yes [N] No [S] Suspend [?] Help (default is "Y"): Y

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the ContosoRG01 resource group from the subscription. The cmdlet prompts for confirmation and does not return any output by default.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Use the Force parameter
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureResourceGroup -Name ContosoRG01 | Remove-AzureResourceGroup -Verbose -ForceVERBOSE: Performing the operation "Removing resource group ..." on target "ContosoRG01".

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command deletes the ContosoRG01 resource group from the subscription. It uses the Get-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet to get the resource group and pipes the resource group (by name) to the Remove-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet. The Remove-AzureResourceGroup command uses the Verbose common parameter to get status information about the operation and the Force parameter to suppress the confirmation prompt.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Remove all resource groups
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureResourceGroup | Remove-AzureResourceGroup -PassThru ConfirmAre you sure you want to remove resource group 'ContosoRG01'[Y] Yes [N] No [S] Suspend [?] Help (default is "Y"): yTrueConfirmAre you sure you want to remove resource group 'ContosoRG02'[Y] Yes [N] No [S] Suspend [?] Help (default is "Y"): yTrue

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command deletes all resource groups in the subscription. To get all resource groups, it uses a Get-AzureResourceGroup command with no parameters. Then, it pipes the resource groups to the Remove-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet. The Remove-AzureResourceGroup command uses the Passthru parameter. As a result, the cmdlet returns a value of $True for each operation that succeeds.
